definitions.definition: to create or prepare something by combining materials or putting parts together
definitions.sensetop: make somethingbe made of somethingbe made out of somethingbe made from somethingmake something into somethingmake something for somebodymake somebody something

examples.text: to make a table/dress/cake
to make bread/cement/paper
She makes her own clothes.
How do you make that dish with the peppers and olives in it?
made in France *(= on a label)*
What's your shirt made of?
Traditional Japanese houses were made of wood.
What's your shirt made out of?
Wine is made from grapes.
The grapes are made into wine.
She made coffee for us all.
She made us all coffee.

definitions.definition: to write, create or prepare something

examples.text: These regulations were made to protect children.
My lawyer has been urging me to make a will.
She has made *(= directed or acted in)* several movies.
It is possible to make a hypothesis on the basis of this graph.
The Environment Secretary is to make a statement on Tuesday.

definitions.definition: to cause something to appear as a result of breaking, tearing, hitting or removing material

examples.text: The stone made a dent in the roof of the car.
The holes in the cloth were made by moths.

definitions.definition: to cause something to exist, happen or be done

examples.text: to **make a noise/mess/fuss**
She tried to **make a good impression** on the interviewer.
I keep **making** the same **mistakes**.

definitions.definition: to cause somebody/something to feel, show or have a particular quality; to cause somebody/something to be or become something

examples.text: The news made him very happy.
She made her objections clear.
Technology continues to **make** our lives **easier**.
He **made it clear that** he objected.
The full story was never **made public**.
Can you **make yourself understood** in Russian?
She couldn't **make herself heard** above the noise of the traffic.
The terrorists **made it known that** tourists would be targeted.
Unrealistic deadlines may **make** targets **difficult** or impossible to achieve.
Technology has **made** it **possible** to move many jobs away from high-cost locations.

definitions.definition: to cause somebody/something to do something

examples.text: She always makes me laugh.
This dress makes me look fat.
What makes you say that *(= why do you think so)*?
Nothing will make me change my mind.
We were **made to feel** extremely welcome.
This does serve to make you question some fundamentals.
She always makes me feel slightly uncomfortable.
Politeness made her go back to see him.
What made you think he was guilty?
What made you go down to the beach so late last night?
What he said certainly made us all think.

definitions.definition: to cause somebody/something to be or become a particular kind of thing or person
definitions.sensetop: make something of somebody/somethingmake something + noun

examples.text: This isn't very important—I don't want to **make an issue of it**.
Don't **make a habit of it**.
You've **made a** terrible **mess of** this job.
It's important to try and **make something of** *(= achieve something in)* your life.
We'll make a tennis player of you yet.
I made painting the house my project for the summer.
She **made it her business** to find out who was responsible.
These improvements will make the city a better place to live.
He's made his firm a success.

definitions.definition: to arrange a bed so that it is neat and ready for use
to decide, guess, etc. something
definitions.sensetop: make a decision, guess, comment, etc.

examples.text: Come on! It's time we made a start.
The plane was forced to make an emergency landing because of bad weather.

definitions.definition: to force somebody to do something
definitions.sensetop: make somebody do somethingbe made to do somethingmake somebody

examples.text: They made me repeat the whole story.
She must be made to comply with the rules.
He never cleans his room and his mother never tries to make him.
We were made to work very hard.
Our parents make us eat lots of vegetables.
His snoring was so bad, she made him sleep on the sofa downstairs.

definitions.definition: to represent somebody/something as being or doing something

examples.text: You've made my nose too big *(= for example in a drawing)*.
He makes King Lear a truly tragic figure.

definitions.definition: to elect or choose somebody as something

examples.text: She made him her assistant.

definitions.definition: to become or develop into something; to be suitable for something

examples.text: She would have made an excellent teacher.
This room would make a nice office.

definitions.definition: to add up to or equal something

examples.text: 5 and 7 make 12.
A hundred cents make one euro.

definitions.definition: to be a total of something

examples.text: That makes the third time he's failed his driving test!

definitions.definition: to earn or gain money

examples.text: She makes $100 000 a year.
to **make a profit/loss**
We need to think of ways to **make money**.
He **made a fortune** on the stock market.
She **makes a living** as a stand-up comic.
A movie with big name stars in it should make money.
Did they make any money out of their invention?
She sold her foreign investments last month and made $75 000.
The company is making a loss on its children's range.
There's money to be made from tourism.
You won't make much money as a shop assistant.

definitions.definition: to think or calculate something to be something

examples.text: What time do you **make it**?
I make that exactly $50.

definitions.definition: to manage to reach or go to a place or position

examples.text: Do you think we'll make Dover by 12?
I'm sorry I couldn't make your party last night.
He'll never make *(= get a place in)* the team.
The story made *(= appeared on)* the front pages of the national newspapers.
We just managed to **make the deadline** *(= to finish something in time)*.
Bob made the airport in less than forty minutes.
The climber was the first woman to make the summit.

definitions.definition: to cause something to be a success

examples.text: Good company can make a meal.
The news really **made my day**.

definitions.definition: to make a movement that makes it seem as if you are just going to do something

examples.text: He made as if to speak.

definitions.definition: to manage with something that is not really good enough

examples.text: We were in a hurry so we had to make do with a quick snack.

definitions.definition: to become rich and successful
to pay for, replace or repair something that has been lost or damaged

examples.text: She promised to make good the damage.

definitions.definition: to do something that you have promised, threatened, etc. to do
to be successful in your career

examples.text: He never really made it as an actor.

definitions.definition: to succeed in reaching a place in time, especially when this is difficult

examples.text: The flight leaves in twenty minutes—we'll never make it.

definitions.definition: to be able to be present at a place

examples.text: I'm sorry I won't be able to make it *(= for example, to a party)* on Saturday.

definitions.definition: to survive after a serious illness or accident; to deal successfully with a difficult experience

examples.text: The doctors think he's going to make it.
I don't know how I made it through the week.

definitions.definition: to have sex with somebody
to pretend to be, know or have something in order to impress people

examples.text: He makes like he's the greatest actor of all time.

definitions.definition: to gain as much advantage, pleasure, etc. as you can from somebody/something

examples.text: It's my first trip abroad so I'm going to make the most of it.
She doesn't know how to make the most of herself *(= make herself appear in the best possible way)*.

definitions.definition: to treat something/somebody as very important

examples.text: He always makes much of his humble origins.

definitions.definition: to be the thing that makes somebody/something either a success or a failure

examples.text: This movie will make or break him as a director.
It's make-or-break time for the company.

definitions.definition: to be successful in your life

examples.text: I wanted to study hard and really make something of myself.

wordOrigin: Old English macian, of West Germanic origin, from a base meaning ‘fitting’; related to the verb match.
